title: How to stop hating someone - Quora

response.answer_text: HATE is such a strong word. It's one of the worst things you can keep in your vortex. If you have decided to stop it then first step is done, let me help you with the second one. Identify your story and apply the solution. BETRAYAL is the story and Hatred is your vengeance.You loathe the person with all the energy you have. Every cell in your body screams hatred towards him/her. If you have this feeling for a person who betrayed you then the most common reason behind this is you blame yourself, that you were not good enough. In the back of your mind you keep on making stuff up, stuff that never even was the reason of betrayal. You get irritated and hatred towards them keep on increasing. FORGIVE. Yes, say it out loud! “I forgive you”, and with that you take the power back. They no longer have the power of making you feel bad about something that was not even your fault in the first place. Hatred is the mask and Envy is the flesh.Sometimes we observe someone and we develop some kind of negative feeling for them. Their way of flowing with the life is something we just can't resonate with. Deep down these people intrigue us, these people make us Envy them because either they are somewhat charismatic or they simply don't care about the norms of society. We look at them and deep down everytime we realise that we can't be like them or they can't be the part of our definition of NORMAL we start developing a negative notion towards them and name it hatred. Accept the fact that they are unique and you somewhat like them for their different ways of living, even if you can't apply them yourself. Accept the challenging views about the universe they throw at you. You don't necessarily have to agree just accept. Your acceptance is rubber and their traits are glue.For example you hate back bitching or negative people or the so called critiques which makes you hate the person acquiring the trait. I understand, I've been there! There is one thing that will go long way with you till you die. That's IGNORING, because you hating them is not gonna change them in any way, all it's going to do is make you angry at every sight of them. The art of ignoring should be mastered by everyone so that it can be utilised at the right places with the right people. Remember! You are not responsible for everything and everyone, so don't bother. According to my observations these are the three major reasons and the solutions. If you couldn't find yours, then remember… The reason will always lie within you, your heart doesn't deserve this kind of heavy negativity. Figure out your own solutions , your own ways , your own reasons and let it go…not for them but for yourself because you deserve better.

i don’t know what made you hate this person? it is very difficult to stop hating the person, but the best thing you can do is ignore it. and sometimes not ignore it. why ignore it? and why not ignore it? the person you may hate did awful things to you, but when you hate someone it consumes your inner mind. your mind will be filled with negative thoughts and you can’t act positive. this hatred can change your views over other people too. for example, you hated a guy because he betrayed your trust and you still dwell with that hatred. later, you find some friends but something happened, like a misunderstanding and you will turn to hate them again, even when this could be solved easily. Hatred not only makes you hate, it will also create a barrier between you and other people. so whatever reason for you to hate this person, make sure you don’t always be consumed by this hatred only. it is for your own benefit to ignore it. Try to avoid the person as much as you can, concentrate on things you like and can take of you, make your own goals and put your mind in achieving them. now I said why not ignore it? it is because for you the person you are hating maybe a bad person and has did something terrible. now what I meant to say is don’t ignore the fact what things has led you to hate him. if this person is bothering you, instead of going against him with hatred alone, add courage, a tad cleverness and work hard and fight against him in a best way. because you can never win with hatred alone. here hatred will act as a spark to start your engine. so I said not to forget it but doesn’t mean you have to dwell in it and turn a blind eye in every step. now finally can you stop hating the person you hate? look everyone is different, we all have own reasons and own morals to follow and you know about yourself than anyone can. analyze your self, how much this hate is bothering you and how it is affecting you. if it is going really bad for you and you realize hating the person is effecting your life try to ignore first. there are many therapies and tips out their on how to calm your mind. the best therapy is meditation. it is really effective and fills your soul with positiveness. if you are impatient and you don’t have time for meditation, go do activities you like and that can ease your mind, make yourself as busy as you can. eventually you will forget this person you hated.

First of all, let me humbly say to you, I feel your pain in this. And I’m sorry that you have to endure this situation in your Life. It must be a challenge for you some days. Let me say though, you are NOT alone in this. I too, struggle with it some days, which is why I can speak of it. After all, there are so many reasons to resent/hate others. I might point out though, that there are many more reasons to love them. But, that is for another time. So, let me share this insight with you…. First of all, I should ask something: is it possible that that, it may not really be PEOPLE that you hate, but their behaviors/ actions that you find you detest? See, there’s ALWAYS an underlying reason for that hate, so You might want to ask yourself at some point, “ Is it the person I hate, or is it their actions?” This may go a long way to helping you become more aware of what you are feeling. Also, remember too that, we get angry over NOT HAVING CONTROL over something, so, you might wanna consider this angle too, when looking at why you hate people so. There might be a little bit of Frustration there. People are NOT their behaviors! Not all the time, anyways. Now, in the case of those who had had some real injustice done to them (i.e. bullying, sexual assault, etc.) their reasons for hate towards others is - in their minds - justified and VERY real. For the rest of us, the reasons are usually more minuscule. Example: we’re pissed off because the traffic’s snarled on our way to work in the morning. Or, the newspaper came late, AGAIN! And so on…. Since we’re going to be late for work - we think that, because of other commuters - we generalize that people are stupid and irresponsible, and fully to blame for all the crap WE have to go thru! Lol, does this sound familiar to you? If so, that’s okay. That’s normal. The worst part of this hatred though, is when you turn that hatred on YOU. THEN, it becomes a REAL problem. So, be careful of that, cause it can lead to Depression… and you don’t want that. In my own experience - and I hope you’ll pardon me for my bluntness here - one way to overcome this hatred towards others, is a constant, and ongoing practice, of realizing that, people are WHO AND WHAT THEY ARE, and they’re ALWAYS gonna do things that piss you off! So you’d BETTER learn to deal with it. That’s right! PEOPLE are always gonna be assholes. And you can’t control that. That’s one reason why I, myself, struggle with my OWN anger issues towards other people. Most times, I tend to think the Human Race is merely a bunch of retarded monkeys! Running around hooting and screaming while fling s**t at anything that’s too hard for them to handle! ( And you wonder why Primates resemble US, so much!) By hating them, you give THEM power over you. And trust me, you’re much better than that, even if you don’t feel like it right now... you are. ACCEPTANCE is a big key here. Of yourself…of others… of Life. You just have to get into the practice.. then maybe the habit,,, of telling yourself, “F**k it! They’re not worth wasting my anger on!” Do this EVERY DAY, if you have to. Make this a GIFT to yourself . The way I approach this myself, is as if I am joking around with one of my best friends. And we’re having a good laugh over it. But, you have to talk to YOURSELF as if you are that best friend. Remember, YOU are the one responsible for your feelings. How can you change them, when you are always handing the reigns to them over to someone ELSE? Finally…Don’t worry about forgiving others for past mistakes / reasons for you hating them. Instead, look at forgiving you, first. Realize the Human Race IS just a bunch of retarded Monkeys, MOST times (!!!!), and accept that that’s okay! (Note: they have their good moments, too!) Once you accept it, and learn to see it as it really is… then you can start to move forward. Accept yourself… and as you do…that hatred and anger will, gradually, shrink to the point where it no longer takes the attention that it once did. Because as it shrinks, YOU will grow. Weird, huh? Good luck with your situation. I truly hope what I have told you helps you. Thank you for reading it.

1) Understand that we are all born guiltless and that life then happens to us. Life is hard and it often twists people. If the person has done something unforgivable, try not take it personally - by that I mean that, it's them, not you.  2) Understand that nobody, except a very sick individual, gets out of bed in the morning and thinks now whose life can I cock up today? Everybody thinks they are doing what they have to do to survive.  3) Understand that letting go of your hatred helps you, not them. To say, I'm not going to be angry about this anymore is not the same as saying What you did to me was okay. It is more like saying, I'm not going to let you keep doing it to me.  One of my favourite sayings in times like this is: Hatred is like drinking poison and expecting someone else to die.  4) Symbolic visualisation of what you want your emotions to do helps enormously. The human brain thrives on visual plans and wants to do what you instruct it to do. It LOVES symbols - flags, dreams and music tell us that clearly.  You can imagine a balloon with the object of your hate inside and release that balloon to float away out of your sight. This symbolic imagination tells your brain that you don't want to think about that person anymore. It will work soon enough if you persist. You can imagine that hatred as a yukky poison that fills your body which you then let drain away out of you through your fingers and toes. This tells your brain that your resentment is toxic and it shouldn't allow poisonous crap to hang around in your mind because that also affects your body. If that person is still in your life and you are forced to unpleasant confrontations, you can imagine yourself as being surrounded by a shield which protects you from any 'bad vibes' that might come from them. This tells your brain to disregard input from that person. You may be thinking How can these things help me? It's all imagination. Well, great news - so are your emotions!  Yes, it's true -your emotions are all in your head. Which is not the same as saying they are not real, it just means that you are in charge of them. Yes, they are an unruly bunch and when they are running very high, it takes effort and clear thinking to keep them civilised, but still, they are yours to command.  Meditation is the greatest tool you can use to calm destructive emotion and there are many places on the net where you can learn to do it for free.  If you have been very wronged, it can take time to heal and release hatred - but while ever you are making the effort to release it rather than to hold on to it, you are ahead of the game.

Hate cannot exist without love. hate is strongest when it comes in the place where love once was. Knowing how to deal with hate is as simple as understanding this fact. It is exceedingly easy to hate someone, say, your ex’s new girlfriend, or your best friend’s boyfriend who is taking her away from you! But it is not always love lost that leads to hate. Years of piled up frustration and neglect too can make you start hating someone. So is jealousy. There are many who end up without knowing how to deal with hate in their hearts, for their siblings, for their former friends, spouses, or colleagues, because they were consumed by jealousy. Or because they feel what was rightfully theirs went to the other person. But, hate need not always be because of someone else. It is as much an indicator of your own personality, say psychologists. How to deal with hate The reasons for hating someone could be various. But that does not in any way change the fact that you have to deal with the people you hate nevertheless. And it is going to harm no one as much as it harms you. The most powerful argument against hatred is that it is pointless. So you hate that person in your best friend’s life. It is not going to make your best friend dump her. All it will do is make things uncomfortable between your friend and you. And make you mad. That you hate someone or don’t know how to deal with hate is your problem, not theirs. Sometimes, hate can also make you lose a lot. You hate half of your team at work. So you decide not to go to that team get-together and it so happens that, that annoying know-it-all in the next cubicle manages to become best pals with your boss over a few drinks, and sneaks away that coveted promotion right underneath your nose. Who’s loss? Hatred for one person can also make you have to exclude, or avoid the people you love. Because you can’t stand being around one person, you may have to stay away from those you love, because they don’t feel the same way as you do. How hate can change your life You could be so busy hating people, that you fail to see love and concern coming from another direction. You may be too involved in managing all that anger and hate at your ex-boyfriend who dumped you for another girl, that you cannot see your friend, standing next to you all the while, waiting for you to get over the hurt and anger. You must understand that patience can run out eventually. Even the most loyal friends can give up and walk away, if they see that no matter how much they care for you and love you, you never notice.Learn to deal with people you hate. It can change the way you feel about yourself and the world. “Understanding how to stop hating someone is simple if you can understand that you’re causing more pain to yourself than the person you hate.”

Hating, Being Envious, Being Angry, Feeling Sad of a Dead/Lost Relationship => Happens because of the following reasons You are still attached with that person - emotionally, mentallyEven though the person does not exist either physically or relationship-wise => You are giving Her/Him a lot of importanceYou feel helpless - that you can not take revenge or give it back in the same coinYou still feel that the person may come back in your life & apologizeYour ego says that - that person has hurt you/insulted you/ harmed you => so why should you just sit & do nothingYour grief cycle has not reached the Acceptance levelWhatever the cause of your hate - IT HAS NO IMPACT WHATSOEVER ON THE SUBJECT OF YOUR HATRED - You are only killing yourself. Now what is the way out - you have to work on it - and depending on your level of attachment with that person => It may take a very long time & it also will be excruciatingly slow process. The goal is to reach the level of acceptance - that this relationship is DeadThen you will also realize that by letting go of this person - how many ways you benefitYou do not have to forget - BUT FORGIVEYou have to get into some passionate pursuits/hobbies - which make you busyIf it is a love relationship - you have to find a new personInitially - think of this person - feel all the negative feelings getting into you => you do not have to resist the feelings - but feel the pain => If you want to cry - go ahead cry as much you wantWhen you do the point 6 deliberately - instead of suppressing => in pro-active way => after few days - you will realize that the pain is reducingIf possible - learn the technique of visualization - from my blog get mood instantly on demand => When you can visualize the hurting scene - make your mind push it farther & farther so that the scene becomes very dull/hazy & feel that the pain is subsidingIf it is a case of rejection - please analyze why your are worthy of better person’s loveIf you keep meeting that person - and it is a case of insult => you have to learn the technique of Assertiveness => please visit our website blog section for more tipsThen you should spend more time with real well-wishers & if tell them about this hurt/pain/insult/whatever => telling them how it is making your life difficultWatch videos on you tube for reducing painFocus on your dreamsRead positive self help booksStart helping people – who are helplessThis is what I did to overcome an emotionally traumatic life shaking experience If nothing works - then seek expert help

Life is 10% what happens to you and around you and it's 90% how you choose to percieve and respond to it. This may piss you off, but it's actually beautiful that we have so much control. A lot of people think that with all the chaos in the world that it's stressful and that we don't have much control over anything. We can have total control over how we view life if we want to. Isn't that amazing? Something traumatic could happen to you right now, and you could choose to make a morbid joke and actually start to have a good time despite everything. I used to hate everyone around me because I believe that self-improvement is community service. I believe that by bettering myself I can better care for and help others. And when I don't see others doing the same - when I see their lazy self- centered, hypocritical selves judging others for not being as good as them - I began to hate them. But through self-respect, I practice empathy. As I grow older I find that I can either accept that most people don't care as much as I do because they don't have enough perspective (which is what I have come to understand), or I could just be hateful all the time. Your degree of outward hate is in a direct correlation with your self-respect. The less you care about how you feel, the more you hate. The more you care about how you feel, the less you hate. Again, the beautiful thing is that you can control it all.

hmmm that’s actually a good question. i’m assuming this question is you acknowledging the problem and looking to fix it, but i think it’d help even if you don’t want to change. If you do want to change, good for you! I’m sure you’ll be able to and i wish you luck! Depending on how intense the hatred is and what kind of group you’re talking about, the answer will be different. For example, if you hate a group of teenagers after they pushed you down and laughed at you, they aren’t entitled to your forgiveness and you don’t have to stop hating them. I’d also say nothing is wrong if you’re talking about hating nazis. But, if you hate someone or a group of someones over something they have no control over, then that’s where it starts to get more serious because i’d guess you mean you hate lgbt people, or black people, or homeless people, etc. In the case of more serious things like those, you should think about it deeply and interrogate your brain to see if you can find the cause. These are some questions i would recommend dwelling on (the example responses are if hypothetically i’m you and the group i hate is gay people) Do i actually hate them?i’m pretty sureWhy do i hate them?they make me uncomfortableIs the reason their fault?i guess not, but i’d rather not see them do anything gay near me or my family. keep that stuff private.What can i do to lessen my hatred?talk to a professionalconfide in a close friend i trust to help me overcome iteducate myself on the group to see if my reasons make sensego to support groups for gay people to hear their stories and see with my own eyes what hate similar to my own has done to them (if i’m allowed to attend, know i don’t have malicious intent, and can 100% control myself if i get upset)If you want more detailed ways to overcome it, i’m going to need to know more about the group you hate and why (if there’s a reason). have a nice day :) it’s possible that your hate isn’t a huge issue if you don’t let it alter your decisions, though. If you’re aware that your hate can hurt people and know not to act on it, then keep your mouth shut and hands to yourself. You’ll most likely be fine. However, it’s not quite as useful because it’s possible your feelings will grow more intense if you keep them bottled up. if you aren’t willing to fully commit to no longer hating them, it’ll probably work as a short term solution.

Hate is a very hard thing to let go of. What they mean when they say don’t spread it is that you can’t go around raging all the time about whoever it is that is the object of your ire. Hate is a kind of obsession, and the only way to get rid of an obsession is to focus on literally anything and everyone else. Pretend that person doesn’t even exist. Cut them out of your life, erase them entirely from your mind. It takes practice, but it’s like getting rid of an earworm. Every time you catch yourself thinking of them, just change the dial. Have a list of things that are go-to topics you can immediately switch to, or activities you can immediately start doing, in order to get them out of your head. In the end, that person’s existence doesn’t really matter. If they’re someone you can’t physically escape, then you have a totally different issue, and the first thing to do is actually remove yourself from the situation that involves them. Is it a parent, and you live in their house? Find a way to move out, immediately. Same for a roommate. If it’s a classmate, ignore them like they don’t exist; you won’t be in classes or school with them forever, and even though it feels like the time drags, it’ll drag less if you find things to take joy in. “Time flies when you’re having fun” is actually true. The problem with hate is that it’s like drinking poison and expecting it to hurt the other person. You can’t drink the poison. You have to let it go, however you can. I have had to let go of my hatred of so many people, and I know it’s a long trek. There are people who deserve my disdain, but in the end, thinking about them just awards them brainspace they don’t deserve. They aren’t worthy of taking up my time, mental resources, or a place in my heart, even if it’s a black place full of misery. They don’t get to be a part of me. Maybe thinking of it like that will help. If you find you simply cannot stop, talking to a psychologist can help alleviate the stress.

Try this trick with an open heart right now to stop hating people. First, close your eyes take a few deep breaths and silence your thoughts Secondly, start to recall the following events—Recall your lowest most vunerable point in life. Recall how you felt when you thought it was over. Recall how cold and dim life was. Recall how much you cried that you literally didn’t have anymore tears left. Recall how alone and tired you were. How badly you just wanted to rest. How badly you just wanted someone to love you and be by your side through your worst time. Recall how badly you just wanted mercy from life itself.  This might be hard, to recall a painful past and reopen old wounds, but it’s supposed to be. Now that you have an intense visual picture in your mind of your worst point in life → picture the person you supposedly “hate” going through exactly all that. Picture them at their worst, and their most vunerable self, perhaps them even crying. You’ll soon realize that your heart is starting to feel mercy and love towards this person. Often times we think that it is just us in the world going through a worst time. But it’s not. Everyone you see has had a “worst time” in their life, is currently going through one or will have one soon and will inevitably have another one later on in life. Let’s pray for strength and good mental health for each other during those times. By doing this excersise you realize that you should just choose love not hate in this cold, cold world. Hating ruins the self more than anything or anyone else. It’s not a pretty energy to carry around in life don’t be a prisoner to hate. That saying — “I wouldn’t even wish this on my worst enemy” has mercy in it. Visually take your enemy to that point and you’ll start feeling mercy towards them and when you can let mercy enter your heart for someone that’s when how you feel about them begins to change.

An interesting question you have asked and one I wish more people cared enough to ask and take action to make the change this world needs now more than ever! There will always be someone that doesn't like another for many reasons such as what religion one follows, where they live, how they dress, or even the career you have. The list is infinite as why someone “hates” on another. Speaking for myself and myself alone, skin color, how much money you make, where you live or whatever religion you put your faith into,etc., never has anything to do with anything. It's personality that makes or breaks how I perceive you. I don't care if you you're a hip hop artist or a garbage truck driver. You're attitude is what stands out. One of the things that I do that helps is that I think of myself in someone else's shoes. If you can see and understand the other person's perspective, you can usually find some common ground to build the bridge and eliminate the gap that helps create the hate. I also think that hating on someone is a waste of time and energy. I want to help be part of the solution rather than the problem. I know I can't change the past but I also know that I can't change the future. I can't help what my ancestors did centuries ago but if it helps, I am sorry. If I could change the past, I would without a second thought! We can not progress as the only race I see that we all are and that is the human race regardless of color, religion or any other excuse haters look for to spread their vitriol creating the problems we as the human race face everyday. We will never solve the hate problem by creating more problems. That's why I don't hate my worst enemy. I want people to know that they can rely on me as a human to help if they need or want it. You want to stop the hate, kill it with kindness I say. Hope this helps you overcome the adversity and help be part of the solution and not part of the problem we all face almost daily as the one and only,human race! Thank you for your question. Good day to you all!

It’s not easy, I won’t lie. I felt the same for many years. But there are a few things you can do: Find one thing you like about every person you hate. There’s always at least one thing, always. It could be that they’re confident, that they have cool hair, that they’re creative, expressive, or kind. It could even just be that they’ve never done anything bad towards you, or that they seem nice towards others.Question. One of the primary ways I learned to not hate people, was to question why I felt that way in the first place. I would question myself endlessly in my mind. “Why do I hate this person?” and to the answer to that I would ask “Why does that bother me?” and then “What does that have to do with how I feel?” and then “Why is this so important to me?” and I would continue to ask why until I eventually found the answer “I hate because of my own insecurities; this person does what I wish I could do, and so I see that my feelings are a sign for me to work on myself” or something to that effect. Whatever the reason is, once you dig deep enough, you’ll always find that there is no reason.Focus on yourself. Like I said, at least for me, my hate turned out to be my own insecurities projected onto others. So I looked inwards. I focused on things that made me happy. I took up crafts and reading fantasy novels and I became mindful of the beauty around me in the world and in people. I would strive to see this same beauty in myself. And I discovered that it was in fact there in abundance.Gratitude. Though I started my gratitude journal after I mostly got over this particular issue, I was still struggling with anxiety and bouts of depression. Now, they’re almost entirely gone. Why? Because having a gratitude journal forces me to actively look for 3–5 things every day that I’m grateful for, that made me happy, that were good. I write more about my experiences with gratitude here: How the Attitude of Gratitude Can Change Your LifeBe patient with yourself. This is very important for anyone to do really. So often in life we beat ourselves up, berate ourselves for small to big things, and we often label ourselves a failure if we don’t live up to our own expectations as quickly as we’d hoped. Patience is a virtue, and it’s been a vital tool in my healing. Learning to ‘stop hating people no matter what’ is a journey. It won’t happen overnight, it won’t be easy, you will slip up, and you will uncover many aspects of your inner self that need healing. So be patient with yourself. Allow yourself to feel the way that you feel and recognise that all feelings have a purpose; they are there to teach you something about yourself so you can better yourself.These are just a few main points that will help you to not only stop hating people, but to begin loving yourself. And that’s the crux of the issue to be honest; hate is just a lack of love and you can learn to love yourself truly and deeply. Good luck to you.

Hate is something NO ONE should ever feel. Hate eats at your soul. Hate and anger, which are intertwined, are emotions that drain you and stress out not just your mind, but your body as well, and leave you open, not just to pain, but physical illness - high blood pressure for one, and also lowering your immune system so that whatever viruses or germs are out there can gain a foothold in your body, and even promotes heart disease, organ diseases, or cancer, depending on whatever is weakest in your genetics and system at the moment. Whatever is weakest will give. Hate is complex, and involves more than anger though. Hate also involves the loss of objectivity and good judgment, frustration, feelings of helplessness, pain, regret, the desire to get even, and often feelings of loss, especially with regard to relationships. There are diffferent techniques to stop hate in its tracks. I am not a psychologst, nor have I had a problem with hate - my mixed feelings in negative situations have never progressed to the level of emotion hate entails, dislike or disdain has been my strongest emotion in any given situation, so I will tell you what I do in those situations, but suggest two things to you to do on your own. First, go online and research how professionals suggest that you approach this problem, or secondarily, if that is not sufficient to help you, see a professional. Seek therapy. Sometimes, talking it through and having an objective third party help you is the way to go. I myself, when get angry or frustrated, or feel any of the emotions I described above toward someone or a situation, find thinking the entire problem through to be helpful, especially though with a view toward thinking about the issue as if I was not the “injuried party” but a spectator, as an objective observer. What would I say to a friend if they came to me and asked for my advice about it, and gave me all of the relevant details. I approach those kinds of circumstances with caring and acceptance and forgiveness in mind, for BOTH sides. Good luck, bubala!

I think hating is a basically anger toward specific people or thing, because that people or thing is not what you expected. So two ways to stop hating: know more about the people or thing that you hate, the second is a little hard: to believe in God. By knowing more about the people or the thing that you hate, you know what they actually are. We are not angry at a fish because the fish has no legs. If we were angry, we would be called silly or unreasonable. We may be angry at someone who made a mistake calculating 24+32. But many people just don't know how to do that. It is a fact, and we shouldn't be angry about facts. But it is hard because we are always angry at facts that is out of anyone's control. A child may be mad at his mom because his mom is poor, and cannot buy him a nice toy. A man may be mad at his wife because his wife lost her wallet.  A girl may hate another girl for the latter one is more beautiful. But it is not because the mom, wife, or the more beautiful girl did anything wrong. They cannot change themselves to make others not hating them. But if there is no God, all these seems worth hating. Why rich kids has so many and poor kids like me has nothing? Why rich young adults has beautiful and handsome girlfriends or boyfriends but I don't? I don't know how to explain to you that you should not be angry about these if you don't believe God. But if you happen to believe God. I think anger is basically dissatisfaction towards God. We are not satisfied of what is given to us from God. The reality is God has provided most of us basic needs. If you are in western countries. We should have much more than most other people. It's our sinful desires made us just want more and better. These sinful desires blinded us, that we cannot see there are many people has much less than us. They need our help. We need to put our focus on them not on the one who has more and better than us. This is how the glory of God can be displayed on his true believers. But if you don't believe God, there is one more way to stop hating, that is to kill your desires. Kind of Buddhist way of living. Extreme examples are monks who live in a Buddhist temple and eat vegetables, mediate and read Buddhist scriptures all day. Based on my observation, it doesn't work. But you can try.

Stop hating yourself, and develop some compassion for yourself. You don’t have to be perfect, or best, or live up to someone else’s ideal. It’s very likely that what you dislike about other people, is what you also dislike in yourself. Psychologists have various terms to describe this, such as “projection” (that’s when you assume that someone else is thinking or feeling something, but really, you’re the one who is thinking or feeling it). Another term, similar but slightly different, is “identification” (that’s when you feel you are the same as another person). People will project their negative thoughts and emotions onto other people, and they will identify with other people when they want to be, or think they are, like the other person. In any case, so you really hate EVERYONE? That’s pretty extreme. Are you exaggerating, or is that really how you feel? Write down what it is about EVERYONE that you hate, or your reason for hating them, then set it aside for a day or two. After you’ve let it sit for a few days, take another look at it, and see if your reasons are still the same. Then ask yourself if you yourself have any of those traits that you put on your list. Hating someone comes from either anger or fear - you’ve either been hurt, or you think you’ve been hurt, or you are afraid you’re about to be hurt. Is one of those thoughts true? If so, who did it or is about to do it to you? Did EVERYONE do it? Was it on purpose, or was it a misunderstanding? To get past hating everyone, you have to find a way to accept that people aren’t perfect, everybody is doing the best they can, yourself included, and we all make mistakes. Usually those mistakes are fixable and forgiveable. But you have to accept that those same realities apply to you too. When you start accepting your own mistakes, and you realize it’s human and you don’t make mistakes on purpose, you’ll start finding it easier to forgive other people for their mistakes.

Try to understand them. Try to understand why they believe the things they do and where it all comes from. This will not eliminate all hate. I’m not personally one that believes hating things is fundamentally bad anyway. However, it will definitely help regulate it. Everyone has a reason, usually an understandable one, for why they are the way they are. Why they do what they do. An abusive person is clearly not to be liked. Yet, many abusive people abuse others because they themselves were abused. A thief might be someone that doesn’t care at all for those they rob, but sometimes they’re in need of money or food and hate what they do. Sometimes they’re desperate. A non-critical thinker can be annoying, and thus thats most of the world, but we don’t really teach people to think critically. So who’s at fault? The one that was never nourished or a system of thought that thinks its unnecessary or not important enough to implement? Or the system just wants people to be dumb, thats always possible. Point is, the average person isn’t looking for trouble and looking to be a problem. They’re just trying to live to the next day and enjoy life in the best way they know how without doing any serious damage to others, unlike what a lot of media might have you believe. But even so, many that do dumb things and intentionally hurt others weren’t born that way. Some might be, the jury’s still out on that theory, but most are not. Point is, it all comes back to something. There’s always a reason, a construct, a logic, for what leads people to be the way they are. This doesn’t make what they do right. It makes it more understandable. Its easy to hate fully when one feels there’s no other solution. But when you might start seeing where things come from and how they work, you’ll find yourself hating problems more and not the people that have them. Problems can be solved and people can solve them. People are living yinyangs, neither fully evil or fully good. Neither fully the solution nor fully the disastrous end. When you see that people have problems and aren’t the problems themselves and see hope for them, you’ll hate them less even if you find them to be disagreeable, annoying, and even in some cases intolerable.

I think you mean, ‘How does one stop hating people?’ It takes all types of people to make the world. If everyone hand the same temperament, the world would be a very boring place. I personally think when a person hates someone he is not hating the other person, but dislikes something in the behaviour of the other person which irritates him/her. This irritant might just be a projection of his own negativeness on another person when in actual fact the other person is ok, and it is the observer who needs to work on his personality . This negativeness in you makes you a hater and you are always being advised to stop being so hateful. If your near and dear ones and friends are telling you all this then it is high time that you started working on getting rid of your negative feelings for others and developing a positive outlook in life for all. Start by focusing on all of the good things that are happening in your life and appreciate what all the people do for you. Some points to consider See the best in others instead of the worst.One of the reasons you are hating others is because you may have the apprehension that everyone you know is just waiting to hurt you, annoy you, irritate you . You need to stop looking at the people around you as irritants or a threat and learn to value the good people around you and to see that they can actually improve your life if you let them. If you give individual people a chance, you’ll see that they’re not so bad, after all. Everyone who talks to you has the best intentions, not the worst. If a co worker or neighbour wants to talk to you or asks you to have a cup of coffee does not mean that he has a hidden agenda for being out with you, it just means he wants to be your friend, 2. Learn to enjoy talking with people. You may be hate people because you feel that they get stuck onto you when in fact you want to be alone. It is not always so, one does want time for oneself but not all the time. Learn to enjoy having a conversation with others/ connecting with others instead of looking at everyone who talks to you as someone who is a waster of your time. Smile more, it does not cost you anything. In fact it takes less muscles to smile than to frown. It keeps those wrinkles away too. A smile will put you in a good mood and will make someone’s day happy too. It will shows that you are friendly and you’re open to conversation and people will be more likely to trust you.Find common ground with people/ similar topics of conversation for small talks. This will lead you to build deeper relationships and to get to know people better. 3 3. Giving compliments. A hater is most unlikely to give compliments . But you should practice giving sincere compliments, thus indicating that you are a caring person not a fault finder or an irritant . Try giving one or two compliments in a day to anyone say an acquaintance or a stranger like you are looking very good today. Perhaps that compliment you give to a person can make that person’s day. Maybe it’ll be the only positive interaction that person has all day, and it takes so little effort. In this way you will develop a positive outlook in life especially towards people and now you will look for the good in people rather than the bad. If you know a person more closely, then focus on complimenting an aspect of that person’s personality instead of just the superficial things. If you compliment more people, you’ll hear more positive returns. All that positive energy around you will will not let negativeness survive.4 4. Open up to people. If you open up to the people around you, you will find understanding, compassion, and friendship. Such positive vibes around you will make you less likely to hate people and more likely to see that developing relationships with people out in the world is a good thing. You don’t need to bare your soul to the first person you see. However, slowly opening up to your acquaintances will build relationships which in turn will lead to friendships. You will find that some people were like you but changed and connected to others. 5. Think of the ways people can help you. Thinking of others as helpers/ guides in your endeavours can also make you stop hating others. Your family and friends can help you in the areas where you are not so strong, like filling up forms for job interviews, cook something, outdoor games etc. Talking to people more will make you see how much they have to offer to you. You may not know, for example, that your neighbor is a computer expert until you talk to him more. If people help you with something, help them in return. This will make you more connected to people and less likely to hate them.6 6. Volunteering help. A hater never volunteers to help anyone. He prefers to be aloof/ self centered. But if start caring about people other than yourself and start helping around, you and the people around you will grow towards kindness, compassion for all living things. Being a volunteer for a few times a month will help you feel more open-minded and it is most likely that you will meet people who will help you develop a more positive outlook in life and see goodness instead of all bad things. A positive atmosphere brings about bonding within the community. Whether you’re teaching kids or elder, you will feel more connected.

Whether you be smart, attractive, thin, achiever, talented or any other picayune reason to stir up resentment …… that resentment will eventually fester into hate and they will find other people who agree with them until they become a movement and the constitution gives them that right to form a group that is built on “HATE”.

You are on the way by asking the question. If I were to hate you, you would not even know about it. I, however, would be the one consumed by hate. So it is important to regard hate as something within the hater, and almost irrelevant to the hated. I presume the hated has done or perhaps been something that upsets you. First, look into why you were upset by whatever it was. How did you let it have such an impact on you? Even if the hated’s actions did cause you serious problems, and even if they intended it maliciously, you need to regard the problem as an issue to be dealt with. You will achieve nothing by hating the author. Even if your logical way to deal with the hated is to disable their ability to impact you negatively, think of it as a solution to a problem, not revenge. Thinking of it as revenge places too much status on them. It is just a problem to be dealt with. If often think this problem has its origins in the bizarre unpopularity of thinking of yourself. That is often seen as selfishness, and so people tend to think more of problems as independent things, not barriers to you getting your way. So what you need to do is fix you vision on the direction you want to take, and go that way. One by one you deal with the obstacles, whether they be things or people or whatever. And when they have all been dealt with, suddenly you are where you wanted to be. Hate can prevent you from getting there, if you dwell on it.

Always try to put yourself in their shoes. Try to see the world from their eyes. Example. Black people might happily want to hate white people because of slavery and the fact that up to a certain time, all the black people in America were forced there aboard slave ships in chains by white people. Now placing myself (I’m black) in the shoes of white people, if I was born into a society with relative technology, telescopes, paper, books, WHEEL, ships and the general trend was for people around me to want to travel to distant lands out of curiosity and because they had the means to do so, and I had done so and discovered America, one huge empty land, would I have resisted the idea of paying for, supporting, or travelling to Africa to drag black people across to work on the land for me as slaves, especially as the books and scientists of “my time” would have told me not to bother about these black people since they aren’t human “anyway”? Well a very difficult and personal question to answer especially as my neighbours and many people I know would likely be doing such in all ignorance. Sometimes we can be extremely wrong and we need divine guidance to sort us out. But for people who run away from religion, from God, I wonder how you will have any basis to validate any divine guidance. In the 1940’s my Dad was in primary school (here, British Colonised Nigeria, Africa) and was clearly taught in science that the sun went around the earth. Before the end of the decade, science taught them that it was the other way around. The earth goes around the sun. That’s science as a guide for you. :-) When you realise that you too are not all that correct in all your views, you might learn to take it easy on others and learn to love them since they could easily be you.

First of all, stop thinking about the person. But, if you can't help it then concentrate on them. Try to figure out why exactly do you hate them. Is it something they said or did which didn't go well with you. Or, you simply don't like them for what they are. You need to know why you hate them so much. Without knowing the root cause of any given problem you can't solve it let alone overcome it. Hating others is like a problem. It is not good for you. If you are hating someone you are harming yourself. The person being hated may not even know that you are hating them. They are fine with it. They are not on the receiving end. You are. You are the one who is taking the whole impact of the negativity created by this hatered of yours. This negativity is going no where. It is created in your heart and it is impacting you only. It is increasing on a daily basis. More so, when something happens in this direction like a quarrel, a physical fight with the person or some kind of cold war like glaring, encountering and disliking anything related to that person whom you are hating. You need to understand that we have been created in such a way that things like hate will harm us physically, mentally, and emotionally. Our brain and heart can not take these things lightly and without a damage to self. They will take it to heart (pun unintended) and it will not have a good and positive impact on them. So, keep yourself away from such things. In the long run they can literally destroy your physical and mental health and you may fall sick just for hating others.

I try to put myself in their shoes. Empathy can go along way, but only so far. If that doesn't work, I ask myself if I might be projecting. I do sometimes take a dislike to someone who has similar faults to my own. When this is the reason, it takes me a shameful amount of time to admit it, but I do get there in the end. If neither of these choices are relevant or helpful, I consider that the person might be very different from me. I have had to do this with someone who is firends with a close friend. I really don't like him because we have nothing in common. He is super insecure and not content with the idea that someone mightn't be the same as him. I’m giving him some space and it's not working. The more I pull away, the more he wants to chat about football, which I hate. He hates martial arts (boxing is better, apparently) and has no idea who any of my favourite bands are. Small talk is excruciating. I am now in the position now where I have to either find something to like about him or give him some honesty. I want to be tactful. I'm thinking of this, “Isn’t it weird that we don't like any of the same things yet we always end up chatting? Let's run down a list of all the things we like but haven't mentioned and hopefully we'll find something in common. Otherwise we'll end up getting uncomfortable every time we see eachother.” OK, so it's a work in progress. My point is that you can try to find something you do like about the person, failing that try to address the issue as a problem you share with them (I.e. You have nothing but this problem in common) or just avoid them. I wish you luck. I'm pretty sure I'll need some luck myself.

I have this picture of feelings like bonfires that burn inside us. Each feeling is a fire. They burn beside each other … We can stop a fire in general by removing the oxygen, the material that burns or drop the temperature below the temperature needed to burn. If you picture all those fires close beside each other: You cannot change the temperature or take the oxygen away because then all the fires are effected … So the only chance is to not put more wood on the fire … If you hate someone badly ask yourself, if you feel like you want to waste your time and energy on them, if they really deserve your attention and if it is doing you any good and helping anyone around you. Think about it for a while and come up with all the reasons, why you really shouldn’t waste a second, because there are only negative outcomes for yourself if you hate. Once you thought about it hard and thorough for once make the conscious decisions to not feed this fire anymore. Stay away from this person, don’t talk about this person, ignore this person completely, stay away from everyone who keeps mentioning that person.Distract yourself with positive people or tasks or anything you can come up with every time you have a thought involving that person you hate. Ask friends to help you to distract you. Try to avoid time on your ow in the beginning to take away time to think. It is going to get a little easier over time, but the first couple of weeks it is good to just completely distract yourself. Any form of energy, any thought, you put on this feeling is like another piece of wood on the fire. The longer you manage to avoid putting a piece of wood on, the sooner it burns down. At the beginning it is like a log, the more time passes it is more like a kindling wood and won’t burn as long. So the first days and weeks are most important. I hope this helps you …

To stop hating someone is never easy. Hate is there because there was once love there for that person. I don't know your story, but still I understand. Sometimes people apologize but not always. For some people it is easy to move on, because they are wired like that. Yes, they are wired like that, it has become their habit. I go to bed daily asking myself, what should I do to stop myself from hating that person. Just go back and think about the situations where you have hated someone but now it doesn't matter what you feel for them now. My hate is going for more than 2 yrs, I don't know about yours. And still only I know how I am going through my life. I cannot share that with anyone. It is my secret. But I know I am strong even though it feels sometimes that I cannot go on. And trust me don't try to stop hating someone, just try to ignore that feeling, punch bags to take out your hatred. Love the people who love you. Cry if that helps you. But I will suggest you punching bags or do some exhausting exercises, run , fall ,swim etc. Use your energy for something else. Don't judge anyone just love them. It helps. If you judge people too much it will be difficult to connect with people. Love, your friend.

Humanity is at its all time best so far. The majority are against violence, we’ve become more tolerant of people who are different, we are beginning to care for our environment beyond our own backyard, extreme poverty is at its lowest and so much more. Look for those good things and you’ll start to find more naturally. Once you can focus on good as a whole you’ll be more inclined to find it individuals. You’ve trained your brain to focus on the negatives. It won’t be an overnight switch but with practice you can change. You have two good qualities I admire: honesty and, based on your question alone, a willingness to recognize and do something about your own flaws. If you’re looking for something to like about yourself you could start there. You may also want to get some professional help. Self loathing and self hatred can be symptoms of depression. If medication and therapy can help you feel better about yourself and others the problem is more likely to be medical than reality. You’ll also find some wonderful people who are willing to help others which might help change the way you see humans. You could also try to find a cause you believe in and do some volunteer work. Make a contribution to something you can be proud of. This will also put you in touch with people doing just that and may sway your opinion of others. Lastly, is managing you expectations and realizing that your opinion of yourself and humanity is not a complete picture. Feelings aren’t facts. Opinions aren’t reality. Perfect is not possible. This is probably the most important piece for you. Your question is a cry for help so you can feel better about life. Asking for help doesn’t seem to come easy for you but I see it. I hope you make the next bold move to feel better and get the help you deserve, even if you don’t feel like you do. You are worthy and things will get better.

You have to stop looking at the group and start considering the basic things about being human. Breathing, eating, sleeping, feeling pain, feeling joy. These are all human things. Stop thinking us and them, start thinking “us”. Every single person on the planet suffers. Even Jesus suffered. Some people are blind, some are deaf, some are crippled, some are deformed. Some are orphans, some are ill. Some have cruel parents. Some have been abandoned by parents. Some have been raped and tortured by parents. Stop comparing and competing. Focus on your journey and how you can make life easier for people around you. Your friends, your family, but also strangers. There is not one person on this planet who has an easy ride. I knew a white male who landed a cushy job at 21, so was comfortable financially when his peers were struggling. But he was cursed with bad looks, so while he had a great job, he struggled to find love. Look at Oprah who had a tough upbringing and is a successful tv host. She went through a lot of pain early and still struggles with weight and relationships. Look at Robin Williams who while he was a successful comedian and actor, took his own life because he felt so hopeless. No one has it easy. But in life you just do your best.

Well, lets see.If I read your post correctly, you don't have contact with this person any more.That is easier to deal with than if it is being renewed in some way. Something is re-minding you of them and then your brain loads in the file. You run the movie the way it originally laid out, where you get screwed in some way by the end. Emotionally you are re-experiencing it like you did before, so have the same out-come. You are betrayed in some way and because of the degree of anger, Hate. Sociologist have a process call stamp collecting. TA (Transactional Analysis) called them trading stamps. http://www.scribd.com/doc/33646788/Transactional-Analysis  There used to be a premium kind of thing called S&H green stamps and the competitor, Gold Strike stamps. They were given for every 10 cents you paid in grocery stores and gas stations. When you filled up a book, you could go to a "Redemption" store and redeem your collection for merchandise. They were similar to a Service Merchandise store, only instead of cash, you took your stamp books. Big ticket items, like a Coleman stove, required more books as did a lot of jewelry. TA therapist see people collecting archaic feelings on a number of other factors.They found people kept stamps on friends, religions, certain cultures, race, family members, political parties, spouses, and society in general.   Depression stamps are for those who market themselves as a victim.White stamps (purity stamps) are from those who get to be blameless and self-righteous.Gold stamps are from self appreciation. These can be ego stamps too but are tracking what you deserve.Counterfeit stamps are where you are so sensitive to an issue, you chalk one up when you are imagining being offended.Brown (S**t) stamps are for those injustices where we were wronged.You can tell when people are going to cash in because they say things like, "Thats the last straw" that's the last stamp. People can tell you about all the stamps if you ask them. They earned every one.   These stamps can be cashed in for "guilt free" prizes. In the case of gold stamps, it might be a trip or a new car for working so hard.   In the case of brown stamps, It might be a guilt free temper outburst, a drinking binge, flunk a test, or buy something.   As the stamp books pile up, you get bigger prizes. One, guilt free break something; one, call the other a nasty name; or one, be cold and act like you don't care; or even one, hit them.   If this isn't halted and turned around, then hard line players can cash the collection in on one giant guilt-free, mental breakdown, imprisonment, divorce, murder or even, suicide.  This process is in a book called "Born to win.http://books.google.com/books?id=7vfoJF0c3GUC&pg=PA195&lpg=PA195&dq=%22Transactional+Analysis++%22stamp+collecting%22+-hobby++-hobbies&source=bl&ots=Iv5w36WVGw&sig=UdN6MstqE5KvkWebhyO3tuKCbNs&hl=en&ei=0FCJTeCqIoSQ0QGOpfT2DQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&sqi=2&ved=0CD4Q6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=%22Transactional%20Analysis%20%20%22stamp%20collecting%22%20-hobby%20%20-hobbies&f=false You have to find a way to reduce this stock pile of injustice that is working you over and pull the energy out of it.  We had a guy in town years ago, who literally dragged two rifles by their barrels on the carpet to the elevator of a high rise hotel. He went to one of the top floors, broke out a window and started shooting people. He killed a few and wounded a number of others. The police broke into the room and captured him. My old partner did the psych work-up on him. His girlfriend leaving him was the last straw. Society had bullied and made fun of him  for years growing up and when she left, it allowed for a guilt-free, cash in the stamps, kill people, and have no feelings. Hate collects till it corrupts the holder of it. You have to find a way to reduce it some how. One of the ways is from the NLP people: Close your eyes and imagine all the items you hate about them and place them all linked together on a movie reel.Visualize a movie theater and go inside, then up to the projection booth with your film canister tucked under your arm.Open the canister and put your film on the projector, run it to the first frame and freeze it.Look out into the theater, make sure the freezed framed picture is in black and white. Turn it that way if it isn't.Now go down to the lobby then into the theater.Go sit down in the front row, center seat and see yourself up on the screen in black and white, freeze framed.Allow your consciousness to pop up out of your head so you are looking down at yourself sitting in the chair.Now allow your consciousness to float to the back of the theater and into that cubby hole window so you are back in the projection booth.Look out in the theater and see you body looking at the frozen film of you in black and white.Now put a safety shield of plexiglass in front of the window to protect you from any feeling shown on the screen.That is a high speed projector, Run the film from the first incident, to the last, in no more than 10 or 15 seconds and freeze frame it at the end.Turn the projector knob to color, so you can see the film in color on the screen.Remove the plexiglass shield and allow your consciousness to float back through the window into the theater.Float past your body and into the self on the movie screen. You are frozen in color in the last frame of the movie.Now let the movie, with you in it, run backwards high speed. Again, no more than 10 or 15 seconds. You are going to walk backwards, talk backwards, everything will be experienced in reverse, back to the beginning.Open your eyes.Now test buy thinking of one of those events. If you were successful in your re-frame, there should be a flattening of affect and hence, no feelings of anger for the issues on the film.This is a basic, but simplified format of NLP developed by Richard Bandler and John Grinder, to refile a reference feeling. There are tweaks I have to do to personalize this usually. It is not the only way to change anger, but is is fairly effective for people who are able to use their imagination.

When I hate someone, it is because I have a really hard time forgiving them. And when I cannot forgive them, I hold onto that grudge for a while until I tell my inner self to feel empathy for them and try to see why they would do such things. Then, I would think over the situation again and then forgive them in my head, moving onto my life. There are still people I haven’t wholly forgiven yet because it has made a really big impact on me. I’m trying, and every time my hatred flares up because of them, I see it within myself and calm down and tell whoever it is that I am talking to the reason why I feel that hatred. Afterwards, I move on to a different topic to talk about. I don’t want to dwell in hatred for most of the conversation.

I think I will start by saying this:Do you have a purpose in hating this person? Also, do you lose anything by hating him/her? And then in turn, I will also ask – do you have a purpose in NOT hating this person? Meaning, do you gain anything by stop hating them? By hating this particular someone, I’m not sure what you will gain, but I am quite certain you lose bit and bit of yourself every day. Overtime, you might forget what kindness looks like, what love feels like, what it’s like to freely feel what you want. In the end, you are blinded by this one person and all you could feel is this intense negative emotion; he or she is the one to “occupies” your mind. You might even risk having your hatred for him or her guide your views of the world down a very wrong path. That, is the one thing you don’t want to happen. By not or stop hating the person, I can’t tell you with certainty what you will gain, but at the very least, I can reassure you won’t lose anything. The only thing you will lose - is the person him or herself and the place they hold within your heart and your mind. By letting go of this emotion, this person simply doesn’t weigh on you or your emotions any longer. Maybe you will still be bothered by his/her presence, but your mind is no longer “chained” to this being. I think hate has as much of a weight as love does. A lot of time, it just seems impossible to simply and rationally tell ourselves not having certain emotions. But unlike love where we will almost always and effortlessly see the beauty/positive side of the person we are in love with, with hate – we actually and unconsciously look for the things to hate in this being. You might thing “well everything about this person is despicable” but that’s only because you are constantly and unconsciously reminded of all the possibly wrong things with him/her. Both emotions are inevitable, but hate is more or less, avoidable. As for “how” to avoid it – back to the first question I asked, do you have a purpose of hating or not hating this person? Do you lose or win anything by having either emotion? If you got that out, I’m sure you will figure out the right way, the way that fits you, to let go of this negative feeling. I will, however, say that after such a long time of having that emotion builds up, it might feel weird to just let it go. It’s weird in a sense that it makes we feel incomplete, like we are lacking something. Regarding this, I think other answers have pointed out excellently that it’s time to replace the negative emotion with positive ones. You know - placing your feelings and attention on where and who you want :)

What's worked for me, and this may shock some, but I start praying earnestly for them. For them to get everything I would want for myself. The Big Book of Alcoholics Anonymous reminds me that any resentments I carry are the one way to get myself drinking again. They suggest praying for the people I resent for about two weeks. That's never worked for me. I pray for others for anywhere from 40-60 days depending on how much I resent them. It does work. I have a guy I hate deeply. I collected every piece of information I could on him. I wrote a letter which would destroy his life. It's in a computer file, ready to go to his wife. Then I started praying for him, his wife and kids. Now, I go hours and days without giving him a second thought. You mileage may vary, but you're not out anything if it fails to work.

This is a tough, but very genuine question. I have a belief and technique that I hope helps. Inside people are two very important, but ever conflicting processes. Our emotions and logic. We feel our emotions passionately. We think with logic and see straight. Sometimes one will override the other. This can create a situation where we are unable to understand why we feel and think so differently. In your case, you find it difficult to stop hating when you feel you really should. When we hate someone, I believe it means we are in pain and that someone is, in our mind, linked to that pain. Our minds tell us that hating is harmful and we do our best to stop. Then that emotion, still raw from pain, jumps in and the hating is renewed. It can be very frustrating and confusing for many people. In my experience, strong emotions, like hate, can be healed through self determination. Not by force, but through support. When you feel the hate growing or returning, mentally acknowledge the hate feeling in your mind, that it came from pain, and that you want it to fade away. Try to be encouraging and not forceful. Being forceful within the mind can create barriers and walls. After you acknowledge the pain and encourage the hate to leave, use logic to explain why you should not hate that person. Tell yourself you want to be free of the negative feelings that hate brings. Remind yourself of things that help you to understand where the hate came from. Perhaps most important, remember that when the hate is gone you will be a happier person. For example, if you hate someone that hurt your feelings in the past, you can explain to yourself that there may be reason you do not know or understand that may be involved. There may or may not be a good reason for what they did, but it is over and you want to be at peace in your mind with what happened. Remember, you are not excusing their behavior. Not even a little. Just allowing yourself to move on and be happier in your life. Depending on the pain level you have, your hate may take a while to subside. Some things I can get past in a day or week. Somethings took me months or more. But you are right, getting past the hate is the best thing for you. Hating someone is certainly not hurting them or helping anyone in any way, but moving on can be so very rewarding. Hope this helps.

Hatred is a state of mind, wherein you feel all the negative emotions stacked against your object of hatred. Here is one of the ways to reduce it. Before practicing it, severe all ties with your person of hatred. Avoid places where he or she regularly goes. You want to give yourself time away. Avoid even getting any information about them in your feed. Day 1: Write down all the hard emotions you haven in a diary. You can even select an online diary. Actually, online diary is safer. It will not get into bad hands. Write it down, write down even the most destructive, even criminal things you want to do to them. While writing, imagine doing all the things you are writing. Done? Cool, the worst level of hatred is over. Yes, you may not feel it, but the process has already begun. Day 2 and 3: Take time out. Do some activities which you like. Day 4: Repeat the same things as day 1. Don’t go through what you wrote on day 1. Don’t delete it either. Day 5 till Day 30: The next few days or weeks, whenever you feel the urge and feel strongly about your hatred, keep writing them in the diary, alternating with activities like fitness, drawing and sketching, playing musical instruments, etc. Day 31: On this day, effects of the above therapy would already be visible to you. You would actually start feeling less intense emotions as you would inflict lesser and lesser damage to your object of hatred in your subsequent writings. Day 32 and beyond: Keep practicing days 1 to 30. You would slowly feel that the urge to write and the intensity of the emotions involved both have started to decrease. Keep persisting with the process until it completely goes away. You may ask why does the process span so long? Its simple, hatred was not developed in a single day. You can dislike a person a single day, but hatred is something different all together. It was built due to constantly living in proximity with the person and constantly disliking whatever impact he made to your life. It also is because, you chose to suppress your feelings or even if you expressed, you were not understood. Unfortunately, the period of letting the hatred out, I have found is significantly longer than the actual period of hatred built up. Good luck! Lose your hatred, things would be more peaceful within you without it.

It’s not an easy question. If this person has done something for which you can seek redress (for instance, a legal matter), you may find that once you obtain ‘justice’ (whatever that looks like) you may feel better and ready to move on. However, sometimes we hate someone because they have hurt us in some way. It’s good to talk this through with a trusted friend or counsellor, and have the chance to express your grief and anger. But it is unwise to remain in that spot! A wise person once told me that when we spend our time hating someone so intensely, what we are actually doing is giving them space in our life - the very thing we don’t want! It also crowds out things we DO want in our own lives - people, events, activities, we use the energy we would give to being a happy person with a full life to thinking negatively about people we don’t like!!! So, think about something else. Not just casually, you have to WORK at it. Every time this person comes into your mind, think of something else. Have a list of things ready to think of, and stick to it. Do things that you have to focus on that have nothing to do with this person, and keep doing things that stop you thinking about this person. Get truly involved with and spend time doing one or more things - work, social life, hobby, that has/have nothing to do with this person. In other words, start living in the world as if they don’t exist. If you see them, nod and walk past - don’t engage with them at all, even casually. In time, you will stop feeling the intensity of emotion you do now, and after that you will soon forget to feel hatred, and eventually you won’t think about them at all - you will spend your time living your own life and not giving space in it to someone you don’t want there! Good luck :-)

Earlier, I used to hate this classmate of mine. I don't know why, but I reasoned myself that she isn't a good person, she isn't friendly with me, she doesn't talk to me, she ignored me...she is bad. So, I hated her. Later one day, she approached me and talked to me. I no longer had the reason to say she didn't talk to me because she just did. She smiled at me often and offered polite conversations always. She was friendly. I no longer had even that reason to hate her.  She invited me for hanging out, and involved me in her activities. She didn't ignore me. I no longer had that reason to hate her.  I still hated her. Remember, she wasn't a good person..she was bad. So, I had all the right to hate her. That is what I told myself.Then one day, I was helpless and broke, and it was she who gave me a hand and supported me. She was my Samaritan. I realized she was good... I racked my mind wondering why I hated her and couldn't come up with any reason. My all reasons for hating her proved wrong. I was wrong. I judged her wrong, and it took me knowing her to realize I never hated her.I thought I hated her. I never did.Just like that, my hate vanished.----------- Similarly, you think you hate everybody and you have built a wall of reasons to justify why you hate them.  Simple, remove those reasons. Don't hold prejudices. It isn't necessary that people act and behave the way you want, but that doesn't render them victim of your hate.  When you can get rid of your judgmental behavior of yours, you will no longer hate people. And, every time you feel you are falling back to hating people, remember this and it will get you back on track:   Not everyone is out there to get you.  Good luck with loving people :)

I’ll tell you a story. I was married to a man who had terrible rage. His father had terrible rage and his brother actually murdered his brother-in-law and is now serving a life sentence in jail for his crime of passion. My ex nearly killed my son with his rage. Anger is dangerous. It causes cardiovascular issues and usually an early death. My ex died at 52. Hate hurts the one who carried it. I was molested by four different men and abused by a narcissistic mother. I let go and forgave everyone. Why? Because I was dying. I had Fibromyalgia, Epstein-Barr, bladder infections, and sinus infections. I recognized my thoughts were literally killing me. We have to forgive and let go. Forgiveness does not excuse the behavior, it is for you. Forgive yourself for being hurt and angry. Then forgive the one who hurt you. You don’t have to have a conversation with the person and as I said, it does not excuse what they did. Let it go, so you may live a longer, happier life. Forgiveness prayer: I’m sorry Please forgive me I love you Thank you. Slowly repeat it for yourself several times and then for the other. I’ve been coaching people how to do this for over a decade. What I will tell you is that those who don’t forgive and let go suffer, gain weight, and have heart and other health issues. If that isn’t enough for you I don’t know what is.

There is freedom in not feeling this way. You will be much better off if you can think your way thru this and realize that hate is a very strong emotion, and one that has no positive benefits. It can and will eat away at your soul, focus all your energy on trying to let go all the bitter thoughts of the time/times when you were abused or mistreated, and entertain good and positive thoughts of peace and happiness and forgiveness toward those who have affected you so. Continually remind yourself that everyone is not the same, embrace the good and leave the bad, learn to be thankful for the joy that you have and it will increase. Be greatful for each new friend that you make, that is kind and nice to you. Soon you will find yourself with a new perspective, and old things will pass away and all things will become new.
