Unless you figure out how to stop hating someone and learn to deal with the people you hate, your life will be more difficult to handle due to excessive hate feelings. Nowadays things seems to work under the influence of hate than any other emotion making it a greater motivation behind most strong actions than love. There is this old saying that, hate cannot exist without love. And most at times, hate is always worst where love once was. But hate is not always brought by love lost but it can also be brought by so many years of piled up neglect and frustration that is, jealousy. Some people find it really difficult to deal with the hate in their hearts for probably, their siblings or their former friends, spouses, or colleagues, maybe because they were consumed by jealousy. According to psychologists, hate is as much an indicator of your own personality and not always because of someone else. You are more likely to have a hard time dealing with hate if you are among those who are generally unhappy and dissatisfied with life. That is to say, if there is something you had a tough time in getting you might likely develop hate for someone whom you think got same thing the easy way. Hate could also be as a result of what you went through in life because your past experiences determines what you are today. There are some people who their hate feelings revolve around one person in an entire group. For instance, you may develop hate for older men because you had an abusive father or you probably hate your boss because he reminds of that obnoxious uncle of yours who always hit on you even when you’ve done nothing. One thing about hate is that it is pointless. It only bring more harm to you. The fact that you hate that “bitch” who happens to be your best friend’s girl won’t make your friend to dump her neither will she get a sleepless night you are the one who will have a restless night instead. Besides you hate her or not it your problem and not hers. Not just that, hate can also make you to loss a lot. For example, you refuse to go to your working team get-together just because you hate and can’t stand some of your team mates and it so happens that, that annoying know-it-all in the next cubicle manages to become best pals with your boss over a few drinks, and sneaks away that coveted promotion right underneath your nose. Who’s loss? Hatred can also make you blind towards people that truly loves you. If you busy hating on your ex who dumped you for another girl, you might not notice one of your friend who has been waiting patiently for you to get over your anger and hate and on the long run, he may eventually run out of patience and walk away. So also, your hatred for one single person can make you avoid other people you love just because you think you can’t stand that person you hate. So, the best thing for you is to learn how to stop hating and understand how to deal with hate and only positive way you can do that is understand that you do more harm to yourself than to the person you hate making hate a worthless feeling. Now that you know how to deal with hate, go get yourself a better and happier life.

TL;DR Try to have genuine, non-emotionally-charged interactions with people from this group. What you want to do is to be able to empathize with the group - realize that they’re people just like you, with desires and struggles just like you. Try interacting with people from this group in a neutral context (not a debate, not a super emotional situation). This should be some kind of in-person (preferably, though might be impossible given the circumstances), non-confrontational interaction. Not any kind of debate, not a conversation where opinions are expressed (because opinions = disagreements = deepening of negative feelings). There are good, funny and kind people in virtually any grouping of people you can imagine. The idea is to be able to think of this group as a bunch of human individuals. By empathizing with individuals, you’ll begin to not see the group as just a faceless monolith onto which you can smear any kind of bias or accusation (since they’re not there to prove you otherwise). By interacting with people from the group, you’ll get to know their stories a bit better and no matter how different you may feel from them, you’ll probably feel at least a little less different after you have a genuine, human-to-human interaction (without any of the politics or theoretical issues). You’ll just have yourself and this individual in front of you, and hopefully you’ll begin to feel the fact that whatever characteristic about them you hate is probably not their defining trait. They are a human being, just as complex and intricate as you. You’ve made a fantastic step by acknowledging your feelings and realizing that these feelings are not good and should be worked on. Good luck to you.

We all have hatred in our minds- when hatred bubbles up - just observe it - don’t deny it or indulge it, don’t act on it, don’t allow it to dictate your words or actions, just observe it, let it rant, then let it go. As Aristotle said: “A friend to everybody is a friend to nobody.” Some will love you, some will hate you, you will love some, you will hate some - all absolutely natural & completely normal. I “fell in hate” with an American named Tyler - it was hatred at first sight, he made me feel physically sick, he made my skin crawl, it was obvious we would never be friends, I was civil towards him, it didn’t go any further than that, beyond that - there was never any need for me to engage in any hostilities with him as doing so would have been utterly futile. Buddha said: “Hating someone is like drinking poison yourself & hoping that it will kill someone else.” Maya Angelou said: “Hatred has caused a lot of problems, it has never solved any of them.” Your mind is a garden, your thoughts are the seeds, you can grow beautiful flowers & remove al the poisonous weeds.

You need to re-wire your brain and whatever triggers it to feel that hate. If you are a believer then I would suggest you talk with your pastor.

Nip the problem in the bud. Here is a sequence: We hate someone when we have become angry beyond a certain level. Our anger is the result of a trigger. There may be history as well. We do two things; quarantine the history and dampen the trigger to an amplitude insufficient to behave as trigger. Trigger is the result of our getting annoyed at a time when we are not expecting something from a person. IF WE PREPARE OURSELVES FOR THE WORST AND LEASH THE IMPULSIVE REACTION, OUR ANNOYANCE LEVEL WILL STAY LOW. When we are ready for any bad situation (and that is for our benefit because we remain in an optimum thinking mode), we are more reason-prone and frontal-activated. We keep busy our executive brain thinking good reasons for a bad situation. Logic provides us many ways a person could behave abnormally and we are ready to forgive for whatever shenanigans one is up to. We consider ourselves superior in the sense that we control the situation (ensuring not feeling proud). I might have hated a chair in the dining room that came my way (!) injuring my toes on a number of occasions but that is always my fault. I set it back where it originally had been lamenting my own hastiness. How can I hate a person if I do not do any wrong. IF SOMEONE HATES ME, I WILL NOT RETURN IN THE SAME COIN; I WILL SAVE MY COIN FOR A BETTER USE!

The way you phrase the question makes it seem like it's not a choice. There's a story of a couple who wanted a divorce. The husband didn't love his wife, but before she granted him the divorce, she asked him to carry her up to bed each night for one month. He reluctantly agreed. Of course, the simple action of carrying his wife up to bed each night for a month changed everything and they stayed together. If love is an action—and I believe it is—then maybe hate is too. I know that hate is the emotion you feel toward a person, but if you chose to love the person with your actions, you'd have a tough time hating them emotionally over time.  If you want to stop hating someone, start loving them with actions.  Or another good option is to end your relationship with this person and forget about him/her. There are 7 billion people on earth, so unless this person is family, why not just get away from them and move on with your life? They're both good options. If they're family, I'd recommend the first option, otherwise, just get away from them and move on with your life.

These two things will be good enough to help you to avoid hating someone. Personally I would like to say that we are a result of so many mistakes we did in our past. So, forgive others as soon as you can. Making mistakes is a natural process everyone follows in their life. Don't hold grudges. Anger is the punishment we give to ourselves, for somebody's else mistakes. Be happy and relish your every moment of life. Thanks for reading.

Rethink your definition of 'hate'. The opposite of hate is not love. Love and hate are actually on the same side of the continuum. The opposite of love/hate is indifference. Consider the idea that by hating them, you are actually loving them too. If you think of the strength of your emotional connection with them as a bond that gets stronger as you nurture it, this bond is very important to you (otherwise you wouldn't hate this person). Try to imagine yourself loosening your grip on it. Let them become less important in your life, and the severity of your emotion toward this person will begin to diminish. Try to relax the emotional bond connecting the two of you and your hatred will dissipate. This probably sounds a lot easier than it will actually be. It will help matters if this person is no longer in your life at all (and if they're not immediate family, that should (hopefully) already be the case). Whatever reasons you have for despising them so much, consider that it is the strength of the bond between you that gives those things power over you. You decide how strong or weak (or nonexistent) that bond is. If that bond were to disappear tomorrow, and you had no more feeling for them than you did for a random person on the other side of the world, you would not hate them anymore: you'd have no reason to.

What is hate actually about? it is our mind’s way fo protecting us. Its a survival mechanism purely as an instinct. If you dont like a person, your body will feel unpleasant sensations and emotions. To avoid being near them, your mind puts the emotion of hatred in you so you can stay away from them physically; thus avoiding the negative feelings and sensations you experience in your body. Hatred is essential in a human. You cant love unconditionally everything. Its unnatural to love everything in this world. There has to be dislikes and likes which balance life. Can you imagine eating sweets full life? Can you like all colors, all kinds of food, every music, all clothes, all people? No. You have choices and preferences. Hatred is a “dark nature” dimension present in all minds and a balance towards this dimension is required to ensure that you don’t become imbalanced in this energy. It’s not the dimension of hatred that’s negative, it’s when one becomes unconsciously lost in it that it becomes negative, it also tends to become negative when you suppress it (maybe you want to supress hatred towards this person which might seem unnatural to your mind). First answer the question: Why do you hate that someone? It’s essential to understand why you hate them. Do you hate because… You are actually jealous of their achievements? Because you cant be like them ever? This is a powerful realisation and you must analyse it further. You feel angry that you cant have what they have. Maybe they have an easy life and for which you had to struggle for each and every thing.Is the person an “evil/bad/unpleasant person” but despite it you want to like them because it is the “RIGHT THING TO DO” and that hating is wrong?Do you feel physically threatened by them?Do they uncover hurtful memories in your past and thus release toxins in your blood leading to unpleasant bodily sensations?By doing deep introspection, you will get to the ROOT of your hatred. Your unmet needs, the different ways you get triggered or hurt all come floating to the surface. You cant force yourself to HATE someone neither can you force yourself to LOVE someone. The solution lies in FEARLESS, brutally honest self-discovery that will lead you to the answers.

OK, I too have struggled greatly with this one and the concept of forgiveness.  All the people telling me that "forgiveness will set you free" just didn't resonate.  Some things are unforgivable and some people had caused me so much pain I just wasn't able to do it.  Then one day, this may sound crazy, but I was watching Oprah and she was interviewing two sisters who had been molested by their father and brothers from age 6 on (talk about unforgivable!)  Then the question of forgiveness came up.  Well, Oprah was also a victim and her definition of forgiveness finally resonated with me and I was able to put it to use.   "Forgiveness is letting go of the hope that the past could have been any different." -Oprah Winfrey

You can start by understanding that the hatred is something entirely inside yourself. Often, when we hate, we feel like this is something between us and the other person. It's not, it's inside yourself, it doesn't affect them, they may not care or even know about it. Often, we feel on some level, that we can't let go of our hate. Like justice depends on us hating them, and to release those feelings is to accept their actions. That's not true. If they were wrong, they were wrong, but that's true no matter what you feel. Your hatred only affects you. Once you realize that your hatred exists inside your own mind, realize how toxic and corrosive it is. Like venom in your bloodstream. It does nothing to the person who you hate, and does a great deal of damage to yourself. Now, if you love yourself and want yourself to be happy, you need to let that hatred go. Put the other person aside. You can't control them, your emotions can't affect them. Decide, logically, how you'll deal with them, and let the emotions go. Decide to be happy. Happiness is incompatible with feelings of hate. Emotions are tricky things, and it can take a lot of effort to properly school your feelings. Acknowledge what you feel, acknowledge how it affects you, and decide to let those feelings go.

Almost everyone is grey. I’m assuming you hate said person because he / she ruins an aspect of your life. You think that that person is doing something morally wrong and you despise them for doing so. You feel that that person is evil and you begin to hate him / her. Initially, the hate is directed at that one aspect. Unfortunately, the problem occurs when the hate starts spreading to areas that don’t deserve it. You start making decisions about that person that are not right simply because of that one unrelated aspect. To solve the spread of the hate to unrelated areas, remember that not everyone is evil. Whatever bad this person does, he / she also has a good aspect. Morality is not black or white. Neither is character. Character is a complex aspect. You cannot simply label someone’s character as evil or good. People have different mixes of various virtues and vices. In fact, good literature often involves characters with lots of depth to them. Various aspects and characteristics coexist to constitute character. Remember that the person that you hate is not completely bad. Do not let your hate for his / her vices cloud your judgement. By all means, go ahead and decide what course of action you need to do to stop that aspect that you hate. However, don’t let that get in your way of understanding the person completely and understanding his / her character.

When we hate somebody we become irrational and obsessive. We even want to physically attack the subject of our hate but may be prevented by our inability to figure out whether it is the right time. Our judgement is greatly impaired.our self awareness and laughter is repressed. It’s somewhat similar to romantic love except that feeling of physical attack isn’t there in love and laughter isn’t repressed. Irrational behaviour, obsession and impaired judgment are common characteristics. So many times we pair love with hatred. Hatred against an individual may be seemingly irrational and rooted in remote anthropological instincts. Hate based on race or religion would probably fall under this heading. On the other hand, an individual may trace the hatred to a past injustice and hence find a justifiable source for it. Having said this we can now think about ways of stopping to hate one whom we hate. We must try relaxation techniques to first rest our brain and it’s irrational actions. It would help to rationalise our stance rather than justifying. Think about all the consequences it can have. It helps to be a little philosophical and trying to forgive and forget. If we did this then I am sure we may at least be able to stop hating and and become neutral. That would help us. Remember hate is like a poison which we are imbibing and hoping that other person dies. It doesn’t happen that way. Hater is much more impacted.

Work on understanding that person, why they act they way they do, how they got to be this way, what issues they struggle with and how the world looks from their perspective. Doing this makes forgiving them a lot easier. It also makes it easier to deal with them in the future because it puts everything they do in context and makes it easier not to take things personally. That being said, hatered is a strong emotion and if you feel it towards someone it can be hard to completely get past that, so a more realistic goal might be decreasing the amount of time you spend thinking about them or decreasing the amount of influence they exert over your emotions (i.e. making it so they can’t ruin your mood as easily as they once could). You might never get over disliking them to some degree, but you can definitely decrease the intensity of that sentiment. I think this is the best approach because it focuses on what’s most important- improving your emotional health.

No, but that’s not a bad thing. Hate gets a bad rep because we misuse it so easily. I hate that there are people that go hungry while the U.S. government subsidizes growers to burn crops. This motivates me to give to organizations that feed homeless and impoverished people. Our ancestors hated that wild animals wold pick off their families while they were out hunting, so they developed housing and cities to keep them safe while they were away. Hate when directed towards a problem is useful, hate directed towards people is counter productive. When you hate a person that commits murder you may be tempted to take vengeance on that person perhaps even killing someone close to him to make him feel the same way, that’s how you get the mob wars in the early 1900′s… possibly even most wars. If on the other hand you hate murder it may lead you to create a system where murder is punished so severely and murderers are found so often that the risk to commit murder is too great to take and instead they find some other solution to the problem the proposed murder was intended to solve. Obviously this doesn’t stop all murders, some people will do it in the heat of the moment without any thought, other will believe they can get away with it even though most of the murderers are caught. Point is, there are good things to hate, and bad things to hate. Don’t hate the player, hate the game.

Your resentments, if not released, are parasitic. When we hold on to resentment, we are only tightening a noose around ourselves. For many people, myself included, we hang on to our resentments because we believe they are justified. For instance, “I want to let go of my resentment towards [person], but: she doesn’t even care that she…”he never says…”they won’t stop doing…”etc etc.When we believe we are justified in a resentment, we are telling ourselves that we have control over those aforementioned people. We believe that we have control over their thoughts and actions, and we simply can’t change unless they adjust themselves to our liking. This belief is just as poisonous as resentment itself. That being said, releasing resentment is both incredibly simple and incredibly difficult. It is both as easy as, and as hard as, letting go. It begins with acknowledging your lack of power in the situation to do anything other than change your own way of thinking. I’ve found that, to help bring some peace to my psyche that’s ablaze with resentment, praying for the person in question helps. I pray that they receive the same love, comfort, and security that I have/want for myself (after all, who doesn’t deserve that?) and leave it at that. I know that I value my time and energy enough to stop using it to actively hurt myself from the inside out. Once you release your death grip on a resentment, whether it be a long-term one towards someone who hurt you or a short-lived one towards the guy who cut you off on your way to work, you will know a new freedom. And with that freedom comes the precious freedom of choice: at long last we can choose to be happy. Best of luck to you.

A mean person hopes that all the other people are mean like themselves and when he encounter somebody who is not mean that can be a reason to hate him. But I think, if one spends enough time on the subject, one will realize that it is the people who thinks most about others are the people who brings harm to others. The original Indian philosophy is to look into the self.

By regulating your own emotions. I assume it‘s not everyone‘s fault which makes you hate them. So, the feeling came from within you, and you‘re the only one who can change it. You start by letting your own guard down, trusting that the people around you are not going to hurt you. In fact, they probably love you, thus they are around you, right? You learn to accept people for the way they are, and some are better than others. You learn to forgive the ones who‘ve hurt you before, because they are no longer hurting you. you learn to appreciate people for being around you to love you. Once you let that guard down, you open up all sorts of possibilities for connections and fulfillment. This is a difficult one. I don't think that you can stop resenting and hating someone. I fear I may have more questions than answers for you on this particular query. Are you being literal when you say hatred or is it a colloquial embellishment? There is clearly some mis-match between your personalities that causes friction leading to your resentment and hatred. Is the feeling mutual? Does the object of your in-affection feel the same way towards you? Are you very similar people with similar personalities? Do you understand why you feel resentment and hatred towards this person in particular? In a practical sense, if your dislike is as intense as your words portray then the only thing you can do is remove yourself from the situation. If possible, cut all contact with this person. Don't see them, don't speak to them and don't associate with them. Move on with your life and chalk it up to bad experience. The one deeper thought I have gnawing away at my curiosity is; do you care about this person? I believe that you have to care to love but also to hate. In my own experience, if there were somebody I strongly disliked I would simply “nothing” them. No hatred, no Ill will, nothing. I wouldn't give him or her a second thought.

The best way to snap out of hating someone is to pretend that they're dead and go about your life as if they never existed. It's best to just cut off all contact, especially if they did something horrible and unforgivable. If for some reason you can't avoid the person, try to forgive what happened and move on. You don't necessarily have to forgive them, but make peace with yourself with your own mind and inner turmoil. Do things that will help prevent you from thinking about them or find a hobby that will help you overcome the situation better yourself. If this person has become your enemy, try to become better than they are. Competition is healthy and using your hatred as a driving force to become a better version of yourself is the best revenge.

There is a wonderful passage from the novel The Light Between the Oceans.  “You’ve had so much strife but you’re always happy. How do you do it?” “I choose to,” he said. “I can leave myself to rot in the past, spend my time hating people for what happened, like my father did, or I can forgive and forget.” “But it’s not that easy.” He smiled. “Oh, but my treasure, it is so much less exhausting. You only have to forgive once. To resent, you have to do it all day, every day. You have to keep remembering all the bad things.”  It is difficult to discard bad memories or to let go of resentment, especially if you feel that you have been dealt with unjustly. You need to pivot your mindset and focus on what you want in your future, on what will help you achieve those goals, and on making a path to get you there. Put the ugliness behind you.

Why do you hate them? I’d start there. Do you hate everyone? Or just certain individuals? The way it’s phrased, it sounds to me like you just hate people in general. If so, why? What happened that made you view all people as bad, untrustworthy, or otherwise undesirable? I mean, you don’t hate people with no reason, but maybe you have very general reasons, nothing specific to any one individual. And that may be part of the answer. Do you even see people as individuals? Or are they all just part of the collective “people?” If so, start trying to distinguish between people. That might help. Is it your goal to be alone? Because you’re off to a great start by simply hating people on principle. Or do you mean you hate certain people and would like to see them differently? In that case, I’ll give you an analogy someone gave me. He compared people to computers. The completely innocent and loving baby is the mother board. The rest is just the programing. It is not the computer that is bad, it’s just the software. If your computer has bad software, you don’t get rid of the computer, you just get rid of the software. So, if you can see the person as the motherboard – that is, as the innocent baby – not the programing, you will find a way to maybe not like the person, but to at least free yourself of the hatred. And that’s in important point. Hating someone does nothing to them. You’re the one it hurts. It takes a lot of energy to hate someone. Why would you waste your energy like that? You get no return on it. And surely you can find a better use for that energy than to hate.

Hate is the emotion but what is at the root cause of this destructive emotion?  Seeing yourself as a victim - someone who is at the mercy of other people's actions. Here is a google search on changing from a victim to a victor... victim to victor aspire now  The belief in evil causes paranoia as well.  A premise in Neurolinguistic Programming suggests that behind every behavior is a good intention.  Yes, that is right a good intention.  Some people commit horrendous acts BUT if their experience of life has only been cruelty then they can only live what they know.  And if you encounter them they are only living what they have experienced which has NOTHING to do with you EXCEPT for the fact that you believe their behavior is somehow about you.You can overcome hate by learning not to personalize.   My Buddhist practice has given me greater insight into human nature, helped increased my degree of objectivity so that I personalize less, and raised my level of self-esteem so I am not dependent upon others people's behavior as an indicator of my self worth.  You do not have to convert to study the principles, here is the first one I encountered which helped me stop grieving over a boyfriend who left me  The Ten Worlds in Brief  This is a great question and I wish you all the happiness your heart can hold.  How to Go from BooHoo to WooHoo in 90 Days | Cassandra James

A very good question: How does one stop hating on people? Hate, many times, is actually a form of love. Self love. If you’ve been hurt, you might hate not only the people who hurt you but especially the ones that may hurt you. That’s just about everyone, even yourself. You might be really angry at yourself for trusting the “wrong “ people. So you don’t trust yourself, you don’t trust others, no one is trustworthy, and that is hateful. That, my friend, is the key. Trust. Don’t have fear of bad experiences. Each one teaches you something that has so much worth. The truth is there are no bad experiences just uncomfortable ones. So, start with trusting yourself. Achieving indifference is an excellent goal. You haven't said who the person is or if you will be having contact with them because of family events. That kind of information is critical in providing a good answer. What I can suggest is a series of steps to create indifference. First, get serious about reducing the importance of this person in your life. Replace that person’s role with somebody/something else. Avoid social interactions with them for at least one year. Stop discussing this person with other people. This is how you deaden their impact on you. Remove all references to them from your social media. Block and remove their contact info. Stop seeing people who talk about him/her or think this person is just peachy. Shift your social life away from contact. After a while, it all gets old and dusty and no longer has any real meaning. Good luck.

"Hate" tends to come from focusing on negative ideas. Often the negative ideas are based on assumptions about people who may be different in some way. Usually the assumptions are based in fear. By finding commonalities you can focus your attention on the positive aspects of the person. For example, often opposing governments tell their people that anyone from the country the government opposes can't be trusted. They breed fear and hatred grows. The reality is the people of both countries want peace and it's the governments that want war. We can obliterate hate and fear by looking at each person as an individual and realizing we all want the same things: peace, security, to be happy and to be able to feel comfortable in our surroundings. Our differences make us unique and we can learn from each other. It's about learning to love each other and respect each other's uniqueness.

This is just my own observation, not based on any reliable philosophical authority. I am assuming you are asking about hate towards other people rather than something like “I hate calculus!.” (Sorry math geeks!) I don’t think you can. Hate has existed as long as man has been in existence. We (the human race in general) are taught that those who differ from us in race, culture, appearance, personality, gender and everything else are to be hated or feared in some cases. I think that often, hate really is based in fear and if you could get people to spill their guts on this topic, you’d see that. Sometimes people hate based on experience — I’ve known plenty of white people who had one too many negative encounters with an African American and so “hate” the whole lot of them (which leads to discussions of racism, best left on another post). Likely, those experiences made them afraid. It sounds silly, logically, but it happens. We want to tell ourselves that we look at everyone objectively, but we don’t — we all come with baggage and ingrained beliefs about “others.” Some of us unfortunately are raised to hate — think of the Neo Nazis and their nonsense about anyone who isn’t white and Christian. You can recognize hate in yourself at least and work to overcome it. It’s a start. But I don’t think you will ever eliminate it from the human race.

Know that they missed on you, and feel sorry for them

First I would identify why exactly you hate them, or what about them you hate. Take it into perspective by taking a step back and looking at the bigger picture. It does not benefit you what so ever to have your energy towards hating someone. Even thinking of how much you hate them is letting them take up space in your head. Do not allow it to consume you. If you are naturally a kind and loving person, continue to be exactly who you are despite hating them, chose to simply not acknowledge them unless you absolutely need to. I don't think that hate is a generic emotion. You haven't told us *why* you hate this person, and that reason would have told me what kind of hate you're experiencing.  Probably the two most common types of situations that inspire hate in young people are 1) perceived unfairness by the more powerful, and 2) jealousy or envy. In both cases, feelings of powerlessness and deprivation fuel the hatred. Thus, working on oneself to develop feelings of empowerment, competence, efficacy, and serenity will starve hatred of the fuel it needs to keep burning. Cultivating mindfulness through meditation can be very helpful. Emotions like hatred are exciting, and can make one feel that one's life is more filled with meaning. But ultimately they are more destructive to the person living with them than to the object toward which they are directed.

I have a mean personality. When I look at people, I form thoughts which will demean them. I felt so terrible to think that way, and I am not so perfect myself. But at times when I failed, I had a big need to degrade people. However, I do not say anything out loud. One day, a Myanmar girl, who did not speak English very well, had to begin a representation in front of my Art class, in the United States. She spoke nothing like English; it sounded like another language. People laughed (not mockingly; it sounded so strange). I had to resist an urge to laugh, too. At last, I chuckled. Then I felt terrible. I suffered from the fear of speaking English for the first time myself. I kept looking away because I knew that if I paid more attention, I would continue to chuckle. Then, a thought appeared to me. “Linh, look at that girl. Observe her yourself. Is she doing anything bad? Is she harming you? Isn’t she brave to get up and speak in public? Keep looking at her. Look beyond her accent. Study her face. Feel good for her.” That moment was when I stopped being a jerk in my own head. I truly understood that feeling bad about someone, regardless of the reason, will do nothing to help me. What do I do? Get rid of that feeling. Some embarassing moments led me to discover that if repeatedly stop oneself from thinking of something, eventually he/she will forget it.

Lets stop for a minute and try to understand what hate is.. If i say i hate someone this means they’re suposed to be doing things that affect me or someone i care about negatively otherwise the proplem of hate would be related to me and me only. On another side, there should be a certain kind of hate twards those who are doing unhuman acts such as terrorism and everyone supporting it. To be honest, I don't anybody. And I work hard for it. Over the period, it has become quite easy. Let me explain you the process. First of all, try to locate the root cause of hatred. Is it because of destroyed expectations, or some betrayal or some selfish intentions of person leading to hurt, some actions not in favour of you, or mere jealous leading to hatred or irritating nature or probably because there is no reason at all (it happens at times). Secondly, try to release your emotions you hold for the person. It can start by reducing your expectations from the person, forgiving the person and ignoring the person for whoever or whatever he is and has done. Your hatred in a way proves you have some expectations and feelings for the person. So you need to stop doing that and moreover be mature enough and forgive the person irrespective of whether he or she deserves it. This is not for him or her, but for your own mental peace. Thirdly, don't think or care for the person. So you move out and part ways with the person if possible. If it's not possible, then try to avoid engaging conversation with him or her or at maximum, keep it purpose to purpose basis for talks. Fourthly, focus on your mental health and mood. They should be more precious than the person. If you get distracted and hurt by the person, you are indirectly giving him or her the power to control you and your mood. So you can meditate or do yoga or try something like hobbies or something. And remember there would be many people who will get on your nerves, but be the better man or woman and remain insulated with respect to your feelings for him or her. I hope I answered your query. Regards, Yash Wagle

Hating or disliking someone is something you cannot stop. You dislike someone when you don't like the way they are or the way the talk and present themselves. You might hate them for good or bad reasons but the end you do hate them. You can't forcefully like someone you hate, you can act all nice around them and do good deeds to them but notice I used the word act. Now may there be a situation where you connect with them and understand them differently than before. You may feel compelled to spend more time with them and thus the feeling of hatred might be dismissed. But as of my prior words,hatred or dislike cannot be forcefully withdrawn.

Hatred is a strong feeling and it depends on the intensity of it and the 'closeness' you share with such a person in terms of relationship. It could be your ex, a coworker or some random person you just hate. But for every feeling of hatred there is a cause. Find out why you hate that person and consciously deal with it. If it is for a reason like you were offended by them then forgive them and let it go. It could even be that you hate them out of envy or for no just reason. But let it go because most people you hate don't even know or care and it is going to hurt you more than it hurts them.

Here's my take: Take a minute and think about the fact that you hating them likely has little or no effect upon anybody but YOU. If you hate them, they usually don't know this (unless you tell them which is likely to have detrimental effects upon only YOU) or if they do know it, they don't care. This why is hate is such a useless emotion. The hater is torn apart by it and the hated usually has no idea of the hater's feeling or simply doesn't care.

One thing that always works for me is to see life from someone else's point of view. Understanding other people's motivations and desires helps in giving you peace over their choices and actions. People rarely do things that are not in some way self serving. We have a word to describe people who do things for no other reason than to hurt others. The word is psychopath and the condition (despite what Quorans would have you believe) is incredibly rare. When you understand that people are people and they are doing their best to make it in a crazy world it's easier to give them the benefit of the doubt and not hate them for their actions and decisions. Unless they're psychopaths and even then I would more pity than hate them.

I’ve been successful in transitioning my hate to indifference over time. You can’t change past events. You can’t change what someone did to make you hate them. You need to process through the reaction and emotions of hate, much like one moves through grief in various stages. But then you stop rehashing what happened and you go on with your life. The more you rehash past, hateful events, the more harmed you are by what was done. Protect yourself by limiting the influence this person has over your thoughts and emotions by just getting them out of your life and not thinking about them anymore. There are more pleasant things.

I am assuming that you mean you hate random people for things, not anyone in particular.  You hate them for using poor grammar, hate their tattoos, wearing too much makeup, being snooty, or whatever.     You could go deep and try to figure out why you are hating on them, but that could take a really long time and you don't need to do that to just stop.      First you have to catch yourself doing it.  Tell yourself that there are many people just like them, so they are accepted and have worth.       Stop your anger towards them.  Keep in mind that they are not trying to be you,  be like you, or be accepted as anything other than what they are, so you don't have to be mad at them for falling short of being what they are supposed to be.       Remind yourself that people are hating on you for something too, only you don't know what it is.

Let me guess: you probably hate them because you deal with them a lot. You can’t control them or stop them from being selfish jerks, so hatred rises up. But if you avoid them, then the hatred fades…at least it did for me. I became more and more solitary, enjoying my life more as I did so, blocking out the annoying humans who seemed to thwart happiness. Now, I work at home and only see a precious few individuals, including my husband and son, and when possible, my youngest sister, who lives far away. Most people would consider this a lonely life but I have a rich imagination and enjoy many things, such as music, movies, writing, reading and meditating. Try it! The hate is not good for your health.

There’s a lot to hate: greed, injustice, hatred, war, the lack of compassion, selfishness, the fact that we tend to pollute the space where we live. Our faults as a species are easy to see. The media don’t help—there’s nothing negative that they don’t thrill at promoting to prominence because it gets our attention, and earns them cash. As to hating yourself, that’s more personal and I won’t attempt to guess at what’s going on there but from my own experience this is a combination of internalizing the opinions of others and comparing yourself to others you feel are better than you, more successful, more attractive, whatever is important to you. Work backward. Question everything you believe about yourself. My guess is that a lot of it is bogus. We all have faults, internal and external. If you have expectations of perfection, lose them fast. Much of what we are we cannot control, nor can we control much of what happens to us. We can, however, modify our attitudes and perspectives. If there’s something about yourself you don’t like that can be changed, take action to change it. Otherwise, accept it for what it is. You are more than all of this. Understand as well that you are not alone in your suffering. Focus outward and see what you can do to alleviate the suffering of others, and more than that, see what you can do to bring something positive into existence. As for humans, take a second look. Look at the selflessness of parents, the sacrifices that some make to benefit others, at activists trying to bring about positive change, at the random acts of kindness that occur every second. No, we’re far from perfect and it’s easy to be cynical, but humans are also capable of marvels. You have to open yourself to see these, and this starts with being kinder to yourself.

Number one: Realize your emotional buttons are being pushed & strive not to be reflexively robotic concerning your response. 2) Understand all are fighting their battles but not necessarily well. There are neural pathways embedded in your unconscious composed of negative and positive emotions. The good news is they can be rewritten when necessary & the good ones given precedence. Consider it a sign to attend to the core principle underlying all Psychological heath - paying attention to your emotions as they come up & positively dealing with them. Doing so can resolve virtually all issues but it is very much like building a pyramid, building the strong base on which to build a life sometimes goes up slowly - but soon enough it goes up very quickly indeed.

Go out of your way to find the good in them. Sitting there and trying to muster up enough oomph to overcome any hate in you won't work. Use whatever love you've got to go out there and find out who they are. See them as above you, and look for the things that put them above you. And also, look at yourself, and see if you hate them for anything you also do (and don't hate yourself for) -- i.e. see if your hate is hypocritical. Essentially, try to connect to them, look (as hard as you need to) for the good in them, and just use the love you've got to step out on faith with them.

Hatred is a cancer of the soul. I don't doubt that it's disrupting your life. Get comfortable. Close your eyes and breathe. Slowly, calmly. In, out. Let go of yourself. Understand that the only person you have the power to change is you. You are not responsible for anyone else's behavior. You are powerless over anyone else's behavior. Keep breathing. Understand that loving yourself and loving others fulfills you and makes life worth living. Think of the people you love and who love you. Keep breathing. Let go of the hate. Understand that it gives you nothing, that it only takes from you. Breathe some more and just relax. Repeat this process every day, as needed.

I recommend you to try former U.S. President Eisenhower's "Anger Drawer": "I make it a practice to avoid hating anyone. If someone's been guilty of despicable actions, especially toward me, I try to forget him. I used to follow a practice—somewhat contrived, I admit—to write the man's name on a piece of scrap paper, drop it into the lowest drawer of my desk, and say to myself: "That finishes the incident, and so far as I'm concerned, that fellow." The drawer became over the years a sort of private wastebasket for crumbled-up spite and discarded personalities."

Believe that hate is hate and love is love. If something is said with malicious intent towards you, it’s out of hate (fear, anger, insecurities, negative emotions or expectations built out of those or emotional pain) therefore isn’t to be believed as truth. It’s in a destructive frequency. Truth would be that person feels some type of way and tries to make those feelings your problem. Is there something you actually did to hurt them? If not— They picked their thoughts which led to their feelings, which are their choices and not your choices. You can’t make someone else’s decisions for them. So, if they blame you for the task of picking their emotions and expectations, it’s entirely illogical.

Toxic thoughts could be very debilitating. First area I would suggest looking into is what are the circumstances that thoughts of these people come up with you? Are other people in your life bringing their names up? Are they people in your life who you blame for missed opportunities? Depending on the transgression they did to warrant your negative feelings, would determine how you address this issue. If there was a significant issue that warrants your hatred, such as sexual abuse, it may require a different approach. If these individuals are someone you blame for your current situation and feel stagnated because of them, your preoccupation with them is serving as a deterrent to moving forward. Identifying the function or purpose of these thoughts would be a productive first step. I would suggest the next direction to go, if you recognize that these are not thoughts that would warrant the attention mentioned above, we identify these thoughts as intrusive, counter productive, and irrational thoughts. Picture yourself as a gatekeeper.  If you allow certain thoughts to enter, you are opening the flood gates to more thoughts.  Do not give these thoughts credibility. By externalizing these thoughts, it gives you a better chance at dismissing them before they gather up momentum. If these thoughts become more problematic and don't go away, it may be helpful to seek out further assistance  to address them more aggressively. .

By hating them, then asking yourself what motivations are behind why you hate them. Avoiding it altogether just helps it to fester and grow into a monster. It’s why our country is so dysfunctional. Everyone in this American culture (if you want to call it that) thinks that by only choosing positivity and happiness that automatically You will be positive and happy. They lie to themselves and deny other parts of the life experience. Life is hell too. It’s suffering and painful. Being blind to these things is a recipe for fascism and true disaster.

Apart from philosophical views, one practical approach is to distract yourselves in to things that interests you. It depends on how frequently you think about the people you hate. A slight introspection on what triggers hate might help.. If they are external like places, people, or some objects etc. there is nothing wrong in avoiding them for a while. If it is intrinsic, due to result of train of thoughts, I would distract myself into doing something that keeps me busy either physically (workout, long drives etc) or mentally (music, watching comedy shows, movies etc.) On a side note, this may seem like a weak approach since we try to avoid the situation. But at the end of day, I find it much comforting to discard and move on with things than simply brooding. And this technique works for most negative thoughts, not just for hate :)

Find a way to start talking to them. Once you are able to have a conversation, you will see all the good and kindness that is in them (I promise it is there) and you will stop seeing only a threat or an enemy. I often see stories and pictures of Israelis who Palestinians who work together and are close friends even though, at a national level, they have great problem that are unsolved. Remember when you talk to one person, they are not a nation, a race or a mob of people. That one person is not responsible for the suffering you have felt and seen. They are one person, just as you are. By talking, you can see them as one person. Over time, your familiarity will allow peaceful feelings to be stronger than hate. Good luck.

Feel the sadness; feel the pain and then pray for their happiness! :) Detach and let time pass. Hatred fades. Love expands.

By stopping to care about that someone. If you hate someone, it means you care. You care either because (A) that person took away something you enjoyed (hate inspired by hurt), or (B) has something you would enjoy but feel you are unable to get (hate inspired by envy). A. When you are hurt, focus on building confidence. Confidence that you are able to get what has been taken away, also without that person. Once you manage to do that, your hate will subside. B. When you are envious, admit it to yourself. Admit that this person who is so different seemingly getting things so easily, has nothing to do with you or your ability to get the same or better. Admit that you want similar things. All roads lead to Rome: you just have to focus on walking your own road to the extent you stop caring about that other person. This is the way to stop hate inspired by envy. Hope that helps! :) Erik

A2A. How do you stop disliking someone? Talk to them. It is quite uncommon to dislike a person as a whole. There are a few individuals whom you will despise completely, but most people will just have an annoying behaviour or another character trait will end up being irritating or unwelcome. If you do not get to know the person, you will only remember the strongest impression you have of him/her, which will be his/her irritating feature. Should you nurture a true curiosity for people, you will learn that everybody has a story, an enjoyable trait, an amusing piece of information or something else to share. In the end, your opinion about the person may change, either for better or worse. At least you will have tried and exercised empathy, which is always good.

Disclaimer: the answer is relative. I haven’t been around for very long, but I'm learning over and over again that every problem can be solved by one solution - education. Let’s use the horrific, violent examples of rising global islamophobia - these delusional people really think that they're doing good, and that there are ‘terrorist’ or ‘security threats’ - because they lack the education to understand. Of course, many of these small minded individuals have become the thing they sought to destroy: White nationalism, born in the USA, is now a global terror threat, White American men are a bigger domestic terrorist threat than Muslim foreigners, The Terrorism That Doesn’t Spark a Panic. Finding the root cause is also a key to this solution - and addressing online communities is a part of the problem. By having these places online, where they can interact with people with similar views definitely has an impact on their behaviour, maybe emboldening them (or encouraging them) - the new Zealand mosque shooter streamed his massacre (which was obviously taken down by host sites) there must have been some audience. I would argue that we could reduce the hatred by having extreme control over these internet communities. Essentially mass-banning, terminations of accounts and deleting of groups which are proponents of any form of hatred. You have to stop people picking up the behaviour, so it’s in early education where we need to stamp out these kinds of sentiments. Some may say it is human nature, or refute the point of education being the solution to complex issues like this because you can lead the horse to water, but you can’t make it embrace multiculturalism.

This is a question with many answers but no practical ones. In my opinion, the development of hate had a survival benefit in the tribal days of human development and helped secure the tribal territory and protect the social bonds within the tribe. When perceived threats were encountered from other tribes, the art of dehumanizing and hate generation was employed to support actions against the other tribes. I will not go into the ERA develop in human history but keep in mind that the hunter and gatherer ERA gave way to the agricultural ERA over a very long period of time. This allowed the tribal structure to merge into ever larger groups of people with common beliefs and cultures. As the ERA progressed religion and other belief systems grew very powerful in the management of human affairs and economic development. Major conflicts developed as the belief systems fought for maximum control of the population. Hate was used as a motivation to sacrifice in support of the belief systems. It is still in existence in various forms but this partial answer is long enough.

That is a tough one. I think you have to allow yourself to feel what you feel. Just don’t act on it. (That is tough as well.) If you feel hate, you feel it. Maybe the person deserved the hate; maybe not. It doesn’t matter—you are living with those emotions. The best path is to try not to be consumed by hate. Acknowledge that it is there, but you wish it were gone. Often, time is the best healer, along with doing certain things to keep that person out of your head. Try hard to stay out of his or her path. Block them on sites like Facebook or Twitter. Write a letter you never intend to send in which you purge yourself of this hate. After a while, you may see a pattern. Maybe you don’t hate this person, but you hate what he or she did. Maybe you can get past whatever that is. Hate is bondage, so it is good to escape it, but it isn’t easy. If you can get to a place where this person doesn’t matter anymore, then you have conquered hate. That doesn’t mean you have to be friends with him or her, let them back into your life or engage with them in any way. You just don’t want your hate to own you and your emotional life. So I would start with that.

Simple. It won’t change anything. It is not going to change who they are, and it won’t change the fact that they are not who you think they should be. Hatred takes a toll on the soul and is a very heavy burden to carry. It doesn’t affect the ones you hate, it affects the person doing the hating. A good example is people who hate Muslims. Do they think it affects us? It doesn’t. They’e the ones holding the hatred, while we are going about our daily lives and shaking our heads in pity for them. So, really I don’t have time to dwell on hating anyone. Life is too short, and I choose to live it fully and on my own terms. I won’t waste time hating anyone. I prefer not to carry that burden.

These feelings are hard to get rid of, but I usually think about three questions. Is this feeling of hatred or anger enjoyable or good for me? No. In fact it may actually make me sick while the person it is directed to doesn’t even feel it. Is this the kind of person I want to be, bitter and mean? No. I would rather move on to something more fun and joyful. Does this feeling make the world a better place, a place I want to live in? No. There is already way too much hatred in the world. I would rather be a part of the solution than part of the problem. Hope some of this resonates with you.  Good luck!

response.answer_text: Love. It sounds dumb and obvious but I mean it. Love is the other side of hate, it's two sides of the same coin. There's always hate behind love and love behind hate. The line between them is so fine sometimes you can't distinguish it and both feelings blur together. Did you really mean to say, “…move on to hating someone new?” Because I wouldn’t recommend putting yourself through that over and over again. If you just want to move on, the first thing you need to realize is that hating our ex takes effort. Is (s)he really worth it? My guess is, No. When you find yourself going over the past wrongs again and again, remind yourself that (s)he’s not worth the bother and deliberately distract yourself with something else. Anything so long as it takes enough concentration that you can’t think about your ex. After a little while, you will find that you’ve broken the habit of obsessing about him/her and will be in a better state of mind to move on.
